abstract.text: An interval from a lower bound up to, and including, an upper bound.

inlineContent.text: You create a
instance by using the closed range
operator (
A
instance contains both its lower bound and its
upper bound.
Because a closed range includes its upper bound, a closed range whose lower
bound is equal to the upper bound contains that value. Therefore, a
instance cannot represent an empty range.

content.text: Using a Closed Range as a Collection of Consecutive Values

inlineContent.text: When a closed range uses integers as its lower and upper bounds, or any
other type that conforms to the
protocol with an integer
stride, you can use that range in a
loop or with any sequence or
collection method. The elements of the range are the consecutive values
from its lower bound up to, and including, its upper bound.
Because floating-point types such as
and
are their own
types, they cannot be used as the bounds of a countable range. If
you need to iterate over consecutive floating-point values, see the
function.
